newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.KOREAN WON CLOSES HIGHER ON BOK INTERVENTION.
newsitem.headline: S.KOREAN WON CLOSES HIGHER ON BOK INTERVENTION.

text.p: The won closed higher against the dollar on Wednesday as the central bank injected dollars to ease tightening dollar positions, dealers said.
The Bank of Korea intervened in early trading, selling dollars in one-month, three-month, and six-month forward trading, dealers said.
"The central bank's intervention chilled trading. The market hardly moved this afternoon," said a domestic bank dealer.
The won closed at 894.30, against Tuesday's closing of 894.60. It opened at 894.70 and moved between 894.10 and 894.90.
The central bank said on Wednesday it had supplied $1 billion on Tuesday to commercial banks to ease dollar shortages.
"The market now looks squared-off in dollar positions," said a foreing bank dealer.
Dealers said dollars were recently drying up because of rising importer settlements.
The won's mid-rate is expected to be pegged at 894.30 on Thursday, compared with 894.40 today.
Brokers forecast trading would range from 894.00 to 894.60 on Thursday.
